When sold under prescription order of a licensed professional, a replacement, corrective, or supportive device, worn in the mouth, including dentures, orthodontics, crowns, bridges, etc.
When sold without prescription order of a licensed professional, a replacement, corrective, or supportive device, worn in the mouth, including dentures, orthodontics, crowns, bridges, etc.

Artificial devices to correct or alleviate hearing deficiencies, sold under prescription order of a licensed professional. This code is intended for sales directly to end consumers that are NOT healthcare providers.

Batteries specifically labeled and designed to operate hearing aid devices, sold under prescription order of a licensed professional. This code is intended for sales directly to end consumers that are NOT healthcare providers.
At home urine-based tests used to detect pregnancy hormone levels.
At home urine-based tests used to detect impending ovulation to assist in pregnancy planning.
An at-home infectious disease test kit that can be sold without a prescription.
An at-home infectious disease test kit that can only be sold with a prescription.
At home saliva, cheek swab or blood drop based tests used to detect various genetic markers in an individual.
One-time use medical thermometers for oral, temporal/forehead, or rectal body temperature diagnostics. This code is intended for sales directly to end consumers that are NOT healthcare providers.
Multiple use medical thermometers for oral, temporal/forehead, or rectal body temperature diagnostics. This code is intended for sales directly to end consumers that are NOT healthcare providers.
Products carrying an Energy Star rating (e.g., light bulbs, appliances, etc.). Please select a more granular product tax category where appropriate.

At home digital or manual (aneroid) sphygmomanometers, also known as a blood pressure meter, blood pressure monitor, or blood pressure gauge, are devices used to measure blood pressure, composed of an inflatable cuff to collapse and then release the artery under the cuff in a controlled manner. This code is intended for sales directly to end consumers that are NOT healthcare providers.

An electronic device that clips onto a patient's finger to measure heart rate and oxygen saturation in his or her red blood cells. This code is intended for sales directly to end consumers that are NOT healthcare providers.
At home urine-based tests used to detect the presence of various drug substances in an individual.
At home blood-prick based tests used to monitor cholesterol levels in an individual.
Ceiling Fans carrying an Energy Star rating.
Domestic air conditioning (central or room) systems carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic gas or oil furnaces carrying an Energy Star rating.
Domestic air source heat pumps carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic water heater carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic appliance carrying an Energy Star Rating which reduces and maintains the level of humidity in the air.
Domestic gas or oil boilers for space or water heating carrying an Energy Star rating.
An in home programmable thermostat, such as a WiFi enabled smart thermostat, carrying an Energy Star rating.
Domestic standard size refrigerators carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic dish washing appliances carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic freezers carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic clothes washing appliances carrying Energy Star rating.
Domestic clothes drying appliances carrying Energy Star rating.
Non-electric can opener.

Water conserving products are for conserving or retaining groundwater; recharging water tables; or decreasing ambient air temperature, and so limiting water evaporation. Examples include soil surfactants, a soaker or drip-irrigation hose, a moisture control for a sprinkler or irrigation system, a rain barrel or an alternative rain and moisture collection system, a permeable ground cover surface that allows water to reach underground basins, aquifers, or water collection points. These products are intended for use at a residential property.
Single or multi-pack AA, AAA, c, D, 6-volt or 9-volt batteries, excluding automobile or boat batteries.
Mobile phone batteries.
Wipes used in the process of eliminating or reducing harmful microorganisms from inanimate objects and surfaces.

Paper based items for household use designed to be disposed of after single use, including the following...Facial tissue; Paper bags; Paper freezer wrap; Paper place mats; Paper plates and cups; Paper napkins; Paper straws; Paper tablecloths; Paper towels.
Includes blankets, pillows, bed linens/sheets, comforters, towels, wash cloths, shower curtains and bath mats. Please select a more granular category where appropriate.
Bedclothes items including sheets, pillow cases, bedspreads, comforters, blankets, throws, duvet covers, pillow shams, bed skirts, mattress pad, mattress toppers, and pillows.
A small mat/rug used to cover portion of bathroom floor.
Towels used for individual drying of persons, including bath towels, beach towels, wash cloths, hand towels, face towels, sport towels, etc.
Shower curtain/liner used to keep water from escaping a showering area.
A bumper/liner that borders the interior walls/slats of the crib to help protect the baby.
Dish towels used for kitchenware drying.
Yarn for use other than fabricating/repairing clothing.
Landscape soil, mulch, compost - residential.
Products for use in non-commercial food producing gardens to control insects, weeds, and fungus.
Products for use in non-commercial food producing gardens to enhance plant growth.
Standard incandescent light bulbs carrying an Energy Star rating.
Compact Fluorescent light (CFL) bulbs carrying an Energy Star rating.
Light emitting diode (LED) bulbs carrying an Energy Star rating.
Portable self-powered or battery powered light sources, including flashlights, lanterns, emergency glow sticks or light sticks.
Candles to be used as a light source.
Qualifying items for purposes of certain sales tax holidays such as cell phone batteries, cell phone chargers, and two-way radios.
Portable self-powered or battery powered radio, two-way radio, weather band radio.
Non-electric food or beverage cooler.
Smoke Detectors.
Carbon Monoxide Detectors.

Portable fuel container.
Non-electric water container to store water for emergency usage.
Artificial ice, blue ice, ice packs, reusable ice.
Tarps, plastic sheeting, plastic drop cloths, waterproof sheeting.
Portable generator used to provide light or communications or power appliances during a power outage.
Power cords used to connect electrical equipment and devices to power sockets.

Gas-powered chainsaw.

Plywood, window film, storm shutters, hurricane shutters or other materials specifically designed to protect windows.
Ladder used for home emergency evacuation.
Ropes and Cords and similar fastening products.
Ground anchor systems and tie down kits for securing property against severe weather.
Duct Tape.
WaterSense labeled toilets.
WaterSense labeled urinals.
WaterSense labeled bathroom sink faucets and accessories.
WaterSense labeled sprinkler body is the exterior shell that connects to the irrigation system piping and houses the spray nozzle that applies water on the landscape.

WaterSense labeled irrigation controllers, which act like a thermostat for your sprinkler system telling it when to turn on and off, use local weather and landscape conditions to tailor watering schedules to actual conditions on the site.
WaterSense labeled showerheads.
A type of consumer electronic device used to play vinyl recordings.
Portable audio equipment that plays audio files encoded in MP3 and other audio formats.
A camera that captures moving images and sound and converts them into electronic signals so that they can be saved on a storage device, such as videotape or a hard drive, or viewed on a monitor.
A camera that captures photographs in digital memory.
A framed display designed to display preloaded digital images (jpeg or any digital image format). Has slots for flash memory cards and/or an interface for digital photo camera connection.
A portable electronic device for reading digital books and periodicals.
Wired and bluetooth headphones and earbuds for audio listening.
Consumer electronics peripherals and accessories. Please select a more granular product tax category where appropriate.
Televisions.
Electronic devices bought for personal rather than commercial use. Please select a more granular product tax category where appropriate.
A portable device for connecting to a telecommunications network in order to transmit and receive voice, video, or other data.
A device for recharging the battery of a mobile phone, especially one consisting of a cable connected to an adaptor which plugs into an electrical socket or usb port.
A specialized computer system designed for interactive video gameplay that typically connects to a television or other monitor.
A handheld portable electronic device used for playing video games that has its own screen, speakers and controls in one unit.
Typically a lithium-ion remote power source for laptop computers.
Cables with industry standard connection and termination configurations used to connect various peripherals and equipment to computers.
Storage drives, hard drives, Zip drives, etc.
Computer Keyboards.
Computer Microphones.
Computer Monitor/Displays.
Computer Mouse/Pointing Devices.
Computer Printer.
Computer Speakers.
A docking station is a hardware frame and set of electrical connection interfaces that enable a notebook computer to effectively serve as a desktop computer.
A device that makes possible the transmission of data to or from a computer via telephone or other communication lines.
A motherboard is the physical component in a computer that contains the computer's basic circuitry and other components.
A port replicator is an attachment for a notebook computer that allows a number of devices such as a printer, large monitor, and keyboard to be simultaneously connected.

A device that connects computer networks to each other, and sends information between networks. The router, as commonly used in the home, is the hardware that allows communication between your personal computers and other connected device and the internet.
A device that scans documents and images and converts them into digital data for use on a computer.
A sound card is an expansion component used in computers to receive and send audio.

An expansion card that allows the computer to send graphical information to a video display device such as a monitor, TV, or projector. Video cards are often used by gamers in place of integrated graphics due to their extra processing power and video ram.

A webcam is a video camera that feeds or streams an image or video in real time to or through a computer to a computer network, such as the Internet. Webcams are typically small cameras that sit on a desk, attach to a user's monitor, or are built into the hardware.
Books or booklets consisting of text or illustrations bound in a stiffer cover than the pages.
Children's books including picture books, painting, drawing, and activity books.
Printed religious books and manuals.
The sacred writings of a religion.
Recognized in the ordinary and usual sense as a "book", except that the product is audio and delivered electronically or on a CD/DVD instead of in a printed format.
Publications distributed to the public at regular intervals that contains news of general interest.
Publications, including magazines, distributed on a periodic basis.
Periodicals, printed, sold by subscription.
Flea and tick products for animal use including soaps, cleaning solutions, and shampoos (e.g., flea collars, flea powder, tick and flea soap, and tick sprays).
Drugs or substance for treating animals and intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease.
Medical supplies available without a prescription and used in the treatment of companion animals (e.g., first aid items such as bandages and gauze).
Food for household pets that is consumed for nutritional value. This code is not intended for food related to working farm animals or animals raised for meat or milk production.
Pet food products offering additional nutrients or functional ingredients.
Substances for treating animals, sold under prescription of a licensed veterinarian, and intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease.

Food for household pets that is consumed for nutritional value and sold under prescription of licensed veterinarian. This code is not intended for food related to working farm animals or animals raised for meat or milk production.
Personal computers, including laptops, tablets, desktops.
Removable storage media such as compact disks, flash drives, thumb drives, flash memory cards.
Ink cartridges for printers.
A globe that could be used by a student in a course of study as a reference and to learn the subject being taught.
A map that could be used by a student in a course of study as a reference and to learn the subject being taught.
Paper suitable for printers.
Books that are required or approved for use in conjunction with a curriculum provided by an educational institution.
Bags designed to carry students' books during the school day. This category does not include backpacks for traveling, hiking, camping, etc.
Typically a small electronic device with a keyboard and visual display used for making used for making mathematical calculations.
A calendar based notebook to aid in outlining one's daily appointments, classes, activities, etc.
Portable locks used by students in a school setting to prevent use, theft, vandalism or harm.

An item commonly used by a student in a course of study for artwork. This category is limited to the following items...clay and glazes, paints, paintbrushes for artwork, sketch and drawing pads, watercolors.
Reference printed material commonly used by a student in a course of study as a reference and to learn the subject being taught.
Sheet music used by a student in conjunction with school activities.

An item commonly used by a student in a course of study. This category is limited to the following items...binders, blackboard chalk, cellophane tape, compasses, composition books, crayons, erasers, folders, glue/paste/glue sticks, highlighters, index cards, index card boxes, legal pads, lunch boxes, markers, notebooks, paper (copy, graph, tracing, manila, colored, construction, notebook), pencils, pencil boxes, pencil sharpeners, pens, poster boards, protractors, rulers, scissors, writing tablets.
A device that joins pages of paper or similar material by fastening a thin metal staple through the sheets and folding the ends underneath.
Pins/tacks to secure papers, pictures, calendars, etc. to bulletin boards, walls, etc.
A handheld computer that is capable of plotting graphs, solving simultaneous equations, and performing other tasks with variables.
A musical instrument used by a student in conjunction with school activities.
Prewritten ("canned") software delivered on tangible media.

Prewritten ("canned") software on tangible media used for non-recreational purposes, such as antivirus, database, educational, financial, word processing, etc. The software is intended for personal use, rather than for consumption in a commercial enterprise. A charge, apart from the charge for the software, for an agreement that is not required to be purchased in order to obtain the software. The agreement entitles the software user to obtain periodic canned software updates, upgrades, and error corrections in electronic form.

A charge, apart from the charge for the software, for an agreement that is not required to be purchased in order to obtain the software. The agreement entitles the software user to obtain periodic canned software updates, upgrades, and error corrections in electronic form, as well as non-separately stated support services, such as consultation or phone support.

A charge, apart from the charge for the software, for an agreement that is not required to be purchased in order to obtain the software. The agreement entitles the software user to only support services, such as consultation or phone support. The agreement does not include periodic canned software updates, upgrades, or error corrections in any form.

A charge, apart from the charge for the software, for an agreement that is not required to be purchased in order to obtain the software. The agreement entitles the software user to obtain periodic canned software updates, upgrades, and error corrections in tangible form.

Grain, as an important staple food, is the harvested seed of grasses such as wheat, oats, rice, corn, sorghum, millet, rye, and barley.
A dough of flour, eggs, and water made in different shapes and dried or used fresh.
The starchy grain of cereal grass used as a staple food.
Cooking oils such as olive oil, vegetable oil, corn oil, etc.

A sweet substance especially from the plants sugar cane and sugar beet, used to make food and drinks sweet. This category also supports artificial sugars such as saccharine, aspartame, sucralose, etc.
Flour is a white or brown powder that is made by grinding grain, used chiefly in baking.
A type of plant whose leaves are used in cooking to give flavor to particular dishes, such as basil, oregano, and cilantro, etc.
Seasonings such as salt, pepper, paprika, chili powder, etc.
Any edible dye, pigment, or substance that imparts color when it is added to food or drink.
Food and beverage products sold at retail grocery-type establishments that are intended for consumption off the premises of the vendor.
A dark brown powder made from cocoa beans, used to add a chocolate flavor to beverages, as in hot chocolate.
Foods and formulas meant for feeding babies and infants.
A dark brown powder made from cocoa beans, used to make chocolate and add a chocolate flavor to the baking process.
Ice for human consumption.
The flesh (muscle tissue) of an animal consumed as food.
Nuts and seeds in unroasted, unsalted, unflavored form.
Nuts and seeds that have been salted, spiced, smoked, or roasted.
Vegetables are parts of plants that are consumed as food.
Cracker bread is a thin and crispy flat bread that is often used as an accompaniment to meals in many different cultures, most notably Turkish, Indian, and Mediterranean cuisine.
Plain Breads include items ordinary loaves, such as sourdough, multigrain, and rye loaves.
Specialty Breads are artisan breads, including cheese bread, olive loaves, date and walnut bread, etc.
Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising between 50% and 75% of the overall value of the bundle.
Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising between 50% and 90% of the overall value of the bundle.
Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising 90% or more of the overall value of the bundle.
Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising less than 50% of the overall value of the bundle.

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising 90% or more of the overall value of the bundle, where all food consists of candy (not containing flour).

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising between 50% and 75% of the overall value of the bundle, where all food consists of candy (not containing flour).
Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising between 76% and 89% of the overall value of the bundle.

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with tangible personal property, with the food comprising between 76% and 89% of the overall value of the bundle, where all food consists of candy (not containing flour).

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with candy, with the candy comprising 10% or less of the overall value of the bundle (food comprises 90% or more). Note that any candy containing flour should be considered as food (and not candy) when determining bundle percentages.

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with candy, with the candy comprising between 11% and 24% of the overall value of the bundle (food comprises 76% to 89%). Note that any candy containing flour should be considered as food (and not candy) when determining bundle percentages.

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with candy, with the candy comprising between 25% and 49% of the overall value of the bundle (food comprises 51 to 75%). Note that any candy containing flour should be considered as food (and not candy) when determining bundle percentages.

Food bundle or basket containing food staples combined with candy, with the candy comprising 50% or more of the overall value of the bundle (food comprises 50% or less). Note that any candy containing flour should be considered as food (and not candy) when determining bundle percentages.

Food and beverage products in a form suited for consumption on the premises of the vendor, described as prepared foods, ready-to-eat foods, or meals. Always utilize this PTC for heated foods, heated beverages, dispensed beverages, and foods sold with eating utensils.
Granola Bars, Cereal Bars, Energy Bars, Protein Bars containing flour.
Granola Bars, Cereal Bars, Energy Bars, Protein Bars containing no flour.

Snack foods including chips, crisps, puffs, curls or sticks, popped corn, brittle pretzels, salted nuts and salted seeds, granola products and snack mixes. This category does not include items such as crackers, cookies, snack cakes or breakfast cereal.
A biscuit is a typically hard, small baked product that would be called a "cookie" In the US.
A biscuit is a typically hard, small baked product that would be called a "cookie" In the US. This cookie is covered or coated in chocolate.

Tablet, capsule, powder, softgel, gelcap, or liquid intended that contain a vitamin, mineral, herb, other botanical, or amino acid and is labeled as a dietary supplement identifiable by the "supplement facts" box found on the label.
Nutritional supplement in powder form, dairy based or plant based, focused on increasing ones intake of protein for various benefits.

A food which intended to be or is represented for special dietary use solely as a food for infants by reason of its simulation of human milk or its suitability as a complete or partial substitute for human milk.

Products in various forms that are intended for ingestion and represented as a conventional food and labeled as a nutritional supplement and identifiable by the "Nutrition Facts" box found on the label.
A preparation of natural or artificial sweeteners in combination with chocolate, fruits, nuts, or other ingredients or flavorings in the form of bars, drops, or pieces.

A preparation of natural or artificial sweeteners in combination with chocolate, fruits, nuts, or other ingredients or flavorings in the form of bars, drops, or pieces and that contains flour as an ingredient.
Ice cream, frozen yogurt, or similar, packaged in a container that is one pint or larger. The default behavior of this category assumes off-premises consumption.
Ice cream, frozen yogurt, or similar, packaged in a container that is less than one pint. The default behavior of this category assumes off-premises consumption.
A soft, cohesive substance designed to be chewed without being swallowed.
A mint -flavored candy intended to freshen the breath.

Dried fruit is fruit from which the majority of the original water content has been removed either naturally, through sun drying, or through the use of specialized dryers or dehydrators. Common dried fruits are dried fruits sold are raisins, dates, prunes, and figs.

Beer is an alcoholic drink that is flavored with hops and consists of yeast-fermented malt. Malt beverage is a type of alcoholic drink in which the grain, or seed, of the barley plant is the main ingredient. This code represents packaged beverages for non-immediate consumption.

Alcoholic beverages created in a distillation process, and are known by the common names of vodka, gin, whiskey, rum, tequila, brandy, etc. This code represents packaged beverages for non-immediate consumption.
An alcoholic beverage created through fermentation of grapes of various varieties. This code represents packaged beverages for non-immediate consumption.
Regular, unsweetened, non carbonated water sold in containers. Includes waters containing only natural flavors or essences. Does not include distilled water.

Non-carbonated nonalcoholic beverages that contain natural or artificial sweeteners, and 70 - 99% natural vegetable juice. This does not include flavored water. This does include sweetened cocktail mixes that can be combined with alcohol. This does include beverages marketed as energy drinks that carry a Nutrition Facts label and contain a blend of energy enhancing ingredients.
Ready to drink coffee based beverage containing milk or milk substitute.
Ready to drink coffee based beverage not containing milk, containing natural or artificial sweetener.
Ready to drink coffee based beverage containing neither milk nor natural or artificial sweeteners.
Ready to drink carbonated beverage containing tea and without any natural or artificial sweeteners.
Ready to drink non-carbonated beverage containing tea without natural or artificial sweeteners.
Coffee beans or ground coffee.
Ready to drink carbonated beverage containing tea with natural or artificial sweeteners.
Tea leaves and tea bags.
Carbonated beverages marketed as energy drinks, carrying a Supplement Facts Label, that contain a blend of energy enhancing vitamins, minerals, herbals, stimulants, etc.
Non-carbonated beverages marketed as energy drinks, carrying a Supplement Facts Label, that contain a blend of energy enhancing vitamins, minerals, herbals, stimulants, etc.
Non-alcoholic beer is beer with little or no alcohol content. In the United States, beverages containing less than 0.5% alcohol by volume (ABV) fall under this term.
Ready to drink beverages, containing milk, formulated and labeled for their nutritional value, such as increased caloric or protein intake.
Ready to drink beverages, not containing milk, formulated and labeled for their nutritional value, such as increased caloric or protein intake and containing natural or artificial sweeteners.
Powdered mixes to be reconstituted into a drinkable beverage using milk or a milk substitute.
Powdered mixes to be reconstituted into a drinkable beverage using water.
Milk type beverages from non-animal sources, such as soy, rice, almond, coconut, peanut, and hemp.
Milk or milk substitutes, or drinks with bases of milk, coffee, unsweetened tea or cocoa.

Charges associated with recurring membership dues allowing access or use of health clubs and fitness clubs. Outside of the United States, these charges are not applicable for services provided by non-profit sports organizations.

Initiation fees are an upfront one-time charge occurring at the time a new member joins a health club or fitness center. Outside of the United States, these charges are not applicable for services provided by non-profit sports organizations.

Charges associated with the service of providing in-person personal fitness training or group exercise classes. Outside of the United States, these charges are not applicable for services provided by non-profit sports organizations.

Charges associated with one-time access for use of health clubs and fitness clubs. Outside of the United States, these charges are not applicable for services provided by non-profit sports organizations.

Charges associated with the service of providing in-person instruction in an athletic pursuit, eg. golf, tennis, skiing, etc. Outside of the United States, these charges are not applicable for services provided by non-profit sports organizations.
A monetary donation for a cause, in which the donee receives nothing in return.
Gratuity, otherwise known as a tip, is money that a customer leaves for an employee or employees that is in addition to and separate from the amount due for the goods or services rendered.

A shipping charge for the delivery of physical goods in conjunction with the sale of these goods. The shipping charge is optional, meaning the customer had other means of obtaining the goods purchased and delivered via this charge. This tax category is not appropriate for stand alone transportation charges that are not associated with the sale of the goods being delivered.
